Reproduction of the original in the Bodleian Library.

div.p: THE WITTIE FAIRE ONE. A Comedie.
As it was presented at the Private House in DRVRY Lane. By her Maiesties Servants.

quote.l: Men' moveat cimex Pantiluis? aut crucier, quod

div.p: LONDON Printed by B. A. and T. F. for WIL. COOKE, and are to be sold at his shop, neere Furnivals-Inne Gate, in Halborne. 1633.

div.head: TO THE TRVELY NOBLE KNIGHT Sir EDWARD BVSHELL.
div.p: SIr, your candide censure of some vnworthy Poems which I haue presented to the world, long since made me your Seruant in my thoughts, and being vnwilling to rest long in the silent contemplation of your Noblenesse, I presumed at last to send this Comedy, to kisse your hand, as the first degree to my greater happinesse in your more particular knowledge of me; It wanted no grace on the Stage, if it appeare acceptable to you in this new trimme of the Presse, it will improoue abroad, and you oblige the Author to acknowledge a fauour beyond the first applause. Pardon the rudenesse of my publike addresse to you, in the number of many whom which more excuse, I might haue interrupted. I am bold, but your mercy will incline you not to despise these (at the worst) but errors of my devotion, and the weak expression of his seruice, whose desires are to be knowne,

list.item: Sir GEORGE, an old rich Knight.
Mr. FOWLER, a wild young Gentleman.
TVTOR, and Companion to Sir Nicholas.

div.head: Scaena, I.
div.stage: Enter Sir George Richley, Master Worthy, Whibble a Servant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Worthy.
sp.p: SO soone after dinner?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo:
sp.p: I am engaged, and must away, excuse me brother.

sp.speaker: M. Wor:
sp.p: Well, make ready his horse.

sp.speaker: Whib.
sp.p: His Worships padde shall be prepared: If your Golding be not ready in a minute, your Worship shall ride me.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo:
sp.l: I shall not need to vrge your care vpon
My Daughter, on whom next the deuotion of
My soule to heauen, all my desires
And thoughts reflect, I leaue her to your trust,
And in my absence doubt not you will be
Both Vncle and a Father.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Willingly, I would depose my selfe from both those titles,
To serue my Neece, her vertue will reward me,
I know shee is your study, in your want
I will put on your jealousie.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.l: It would not
Become me to confine your entertainments,
Of friends and visitants, but remember Brother,
Shee's now my sole heyre, and by the late death
Or her twinne Sister, shee deriues the right
Of all my wealth to her, Gallants I feare
I'th Towne hold too fruitfull intelligence
In these affaires, and if they be not watched
They'l with their wit charme all the Dragons guard, these golden apples.

sp.speaker: Worth.
sp.p: There are such indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.l: Oh sir, there are too many, not a Virgin
Left by her friends heyre to a noble fortune,
But shee's in danger of a Marriage
To some puft Title, what are these enter the Garden?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: The Gentlemen that din'd with vs—

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Why how now Franck, grown musty on a sud-dain? Head hung, and playing the thiefe thus with your friends, to steale your person from vs, what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Very like, and yet you leaue our company for this nothing.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Let's in againe to the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: What's he.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: One Master Fowler a reputed wit
I'th Towne, affected by young Gentlemen
For his Converse, yet liues vpon no pension
But his owne Fortune, and a Faire one.
Th'other Mr. Clare, a friend to Mr. Aymwell, whom they both seeme to sollicite.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Mr. Aymwell.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: A hopefull Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.l: Brother, did you not obserue at dinner
His eyes shoote beames vpon my Daughter (more
Then I was pleas'd with) Mr. Aymwell call you him,
I may suspect vniustly, but such lookes are often loose conveyers.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Make no part of him your feare.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p:
I doe not, when I call to mind my Daughters vertue and obedience,
Shee knowes my purpose to dispose her to Sir Nicolas Treedle.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: And how doe you find her inclination?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: As I would direct it.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: She will maintaine it to your comfort Sir,
How euer with what vigilance becomes me,
I will preserue it, while shee remaines within my custody.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: Ile leaue a Seruant to waite vpon her.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Braines.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: He is a cunning fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.l: He has a sconce,
Carryes some subtilty which he employes
Still honestly in discharge of any trust committed to him.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.l: And 'tis his pride.
He was nere o're-reached in any action.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: He knowes his charge.

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.l: Perfectly, but I loose time, Sir Nicolas
Treedle expects me, this night i'the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: When dee returne?

sp.speaker: Sir Geo.
sp.l: Within these three dayes at most,
Trouble your selfe no further.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Ile waite on you to your horse Sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Sh'as shot a fire into my bosome, from
Her eye, or I haue drawne in, at mine owne,
Loue poyson. Oh my starres were too vngentle
To poynt her out the Mistris of my thoughts,
Who is so much like them, aboue the hope
Of euer clyming too, I see a fatall
Impossibility deuide vs, yet
The more I would discharge this new guest, it
Strengthens it selfe within mee, and renewes
Vigour to keepe possession, shees aboue mee
And her great fortune makes my expectation
So dull and painfull, a great heyre her vncle?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Mr. Aymwell what alone, come lets
To cards, where be the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Within Sir.
H'as Sir George Richley left vs?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Some affaires importun'd his departure.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: When shall wee expect him?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Three dayes hence, this your enquirie
Doth promise you haue businesse with him.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Little,
But you did motion cards, Ile chuse my partner
And for a set or two I'me at your seruice.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Make your owne election.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Why dee mocke mee.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: How mocke you.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Yes?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: You doe not meane in earnest.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: I shall betray my passion.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I find him.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: You may for I am lost. Enter Mrs. Violette.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Hee's here— good Vncle, is my father gone?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Yes, gentle Neece.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Delight in both your walkes
Ile take this Arbor.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: So breakes the day and hides it selfe agen
Among the Westerne shades, were shee to dwell
Within your garden it should need no sunne.
Her smiles were powerfull to infuse a warmth
Into the flowers, her breath perfume your arbours
The trees grow rich in blossome and beare fruit
At the same instant, as 'twere euer Spring
And euer Summer when shee seates her selfe
Within some bower, the feathered Quiristers
Shall play theyr musicke to her and take pride
To warble aery notes till shee be weary,
Which when shee shall but with one Accent of
Her owne expresse, an hundred Nightingales
Shall fall downe dead from the soft boughes before her
For griefe to be orechaunted.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Here's prety madnes.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: 'Tis so, you haue done my passion iustice Sir
For loue is but a stragling from our reason.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: If you doe loue my Neece, let you and I
Talke out of Metaphor.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: You know my Father.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Hee was my noble friend.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: For his sake, giue me your free answere to
One question.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: What is't, promise your selfe
What I can doe or say is at your seruice.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Is there a possibility, admit
I loved your Neece, shee might be wonne at last
To be my wife.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Ile not dispute the extent
Of what is possible, yet my answere may be
Satisfactory.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: You were ever generous.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: I were vnciuill not to reply to
A question, you shall finde my loue more fruitfull,
You shall haue both my answere and my counsell.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Let me imbrace a perfect friend.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: D'ee know what
Fortune my young Neece may bring her husband.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: I guesse a great one, but I set more value
Vpon her person, my affection springs
Not from her wealth.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: But yet her portion
Is worth your taking notice Master Aymwell,
Her Father is a man who though he write
Himselfe but Knight, keepes a warme house i'th Countrey
'Mongst his Tenants, takes no Lordly pride
To trauell with a Footman and a Page
To London, humbly rides th old fashion
With halfe a douzen wholesome Liueries,
To whom he gives Christian wages and not countenance
Alone to liue on, can spend by th' yeare
Eight hundred pounds, and put vp fine sleepes quietly
Without dreaming on Morgages or Statutes
Or such like curses on his Land, can number
May be ten thousand pound in ready coyne
Of's owne, yet neuer bought an office for't
Ha's plate no question, and Iewels too
In's old Ladies cabinet, beside
Other things worth an Inuentory, and all this
His daughter is an heyre too, now pray tell mee
What's your reuenue?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Some 3. hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Per annum? Grant it, what expectation
Haue you abroad?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: That's quickly summon'd.
You haue not made your loue knowne to my Neece yet.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: No, my intention was to preacquaint you.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Y'haue done wisely, doe not thinke on her
When y'are at prayers, she will but puzzell
Your deuotion, theres no hope of her.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I meane for you to arriue at her, your owne disparity in fortune.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: I doe finde it.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Excuse my plainnesse sir, her Father lookes
A great deale higher, and to take away
Your least incouragement, to prosecute
Within my knowledge she's design'd already
To a wealthy Gentleman, and within few dayes
'Twill be a marriage, you shall but procure
Your owne affliction to employ your hope
Where things remaine so desperate.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: you doe your selfe more right.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: If such affaires
Haue past, it were not noble to continue
This path, y'aue done me gentle office Sir
I must beleeue y'are generous, this new flame
My reason shall suppresse, before it growe
Too mighty for mee.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: It becomes you well,
Loue like to sinne, inueterate is strong
He preuents danger, that destroyes it yong.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Come to your freinds. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: Your soft Starres will not let you be so cruell
Lady, to giue repulse to a louer.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Doe not belieue him, he does but complement,
I ha' knowne him court a hundred, with as much
Formalitie, wooed 'em ith nuptiall cut, made verses
O' their haire, set Lillies and Rosies, a whole
sp.p: Garden i'their cheekes, cherries i'their lippes, stellifie their eyes, and yet in a twinckling.—

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: Sure you doe him wrong sir.

sp.speaker: Clare.
sp.p: Wrong?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: He measures my affection by the length of his own, Prethee Satyre chuse another walke, and leaue vs to inioy this, thou knowst not my intent.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Thou mayst be honest with one, and that's a miracle
and will aske a strong faith to beleeue it, I hope shee has more wit then to trust your voluble courtship, Ile seeke out my friend Aymwell. Vio. comes from the Arbor.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Sir, if your engagement require no hast.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: I doe wonder a Gentleman of your knowledge should so deceive himselfe.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Expresse your selfe Fairest.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: Faire sir, I am not taken with your flatteries, I can see through you.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: If you haue so actiue an eye Lady, you may see a throng of Passions flaming at my hart, set a fire by your beauty I protest t'ee; come, shame not your wisdome to beleeue report or opinion ath' world, 'tis a malicious age we liue in, if your eares haue beene abused with any ill noise, a me you shall tell your selfe if you loue me, the world is a shamelesse and miserable detractor, you doe not despise me Lady.—

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: No, I pitty so handsome a Gentleman, and of So faire a fortune, should want his eyes.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: How blind?

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: To your owne follies sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Shall I sweare I loue you, as I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: As you are a Gentleman, I know you can sweare any thing t'is a fashion y'are most constant in, to bee religiously wicked, an oath in your mouth and a reseruation in your hearts is a common Courtship, doe not sweare as you are a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: As I am an honest man.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: Out vpon't, that's a worse, my Taylor couzened me t'oher day with the same oath, saue your credit and let swearing alone, I dare take your word.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Well sayd.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: For a greater matter, but not for this, you and I ha not eaten a bushell of salt yet, in time I may be conuerted, and thinke your tongue and heart keepe house together, for at this time I presume they are very farre a sunder.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Would you haue my tongue in my heart Lady?

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: No by my troth, I would rather finde your heart in your tongue, but you are valiant, and 'tis onely feare they say, brings a mans heart vp to his mouth.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Why, your wit is a tyrant now, pray tell me doe not you loue me mightily now aboue Potatoes, come I see the little blind Boy in your eyes already.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: Loue you Sir?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Yes, I know by your bitternesse you wish me well and thinke there is some hope I may be wonne too, you take paines to whip me so handsomely, come Ile be a good child and kisse the rod.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You oblige my seruice to you, I am one
Aymwell called friend, and shall be happy to
Convay him any knowledge may concerne him.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Then briefly thus I vnderstand he loues mee
Pray you doe him the true office of a friend
And councell him desist, I am dispos'd of
Already in my fathers thoughts, and must
Shew my obedience, he shall beget
But his owne trouble, if he moue it to
My Vnckle or my Father, and perhaps
Draw their suspition and displeasure
On me too, by so indiscreet proceeding,
I would not haue a Gentleman of his worth
Doe himselfe so great iniury to runne
A course of so much hazard, if you please
To beare the burden of my thankes for his
On my part vndeseru'd opinion,
And make him sensible, in time hee may
Place his affection where he may expect
Better returne, you shall discharge a friendship
To him, and with it make my thoughts your debtor.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You haue exprest a noblenesse in this
Were all of your mind Lady,
There would be lesse Willow worne.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: You would ha' me praise you now, I could ramble in your commendation.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I thinke so.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p:
Dee but thinke so, why you shall heare mee, Your hayres are Cupids Nets, a Forehead like the fayrest coast of heauen without a cloud, your eybrow is loues bow
whiles eyther Eye are arrowes drawne to wound, your lips the Temple or sacred phane of kisses often as they meere exchanging Roses your tongue Loues lightning, necke the Milky path or throne where sit the Graces, doe not I know that I haue abused you all this while, or doe you thinke I loue you a thought the better, or with all my Poeticall daubings can alter the complection of a hayre now.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I would not haue you sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: No dispraise te'e
I haue seene as handsome a woman
sp.p: Ride vpon a sacke to Market, that neuer knew the impulsion of a Coate or the price of a Stammell petticoate, and I ha seene a worse face in a Countesse; what's that? Must ye be proud because men doe call you handsome, and yet though wee are so foolish to tell you so, you might haue more wit then to beeleeue it, your eyes may be matcht I hope, for your nose there be richer in our sexe, t'is true that you haue colour for your hayre wee graunt it, and for your cheekes, but what doe your teeth stand you in Lady, your lips are pretty but you lay 'em too open and men breath too much vpon 'em, for your tongue wee all leaue you ther's no contesting, your hand is fine but your gloues whiter, and for your leg, if the commendation or goodnesse of it bee in the small, there be bad enow in Gentlemens stockings to compare with it; come remember y'are imperfect creatures without a man, be not you a Goddesse I know y'are mortall, and had rather make you my companion then my Idoll, this is no flattery now.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Where be these Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: How now Franck.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: You looke well to your charge Braines.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: A question Sir, pray you, are you married Sir?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Why dost thou aske?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Because you should answere me
I cannot see't in your forehead Sir,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: How now my officious Trencher squire.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Excuse him Master Clare, t'is his blunt zeale
To doe his Master seruice, who enioy'd
His best care and vigilance vpon this
Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I am married Sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Then I hope y'aue met with your match already I ha nothing to say tee.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: This fellow's mad.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Nor my Master neither, though he left his braines behind him, I hope a man may aske a question Sir.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Come hither Braines.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Ame life thou art in loue.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You are not.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Doe not mistake your selfe for I am.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Caught, I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: No indeed not caught neyther, therefore be not ouerioy'd good morality, why dost thou thinke it possible a womans face or any thing without her can inchaunt me.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Let me alone. Exit Vncle.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Why dost thou court 'em then.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Why, to try their wits with which I sharpen my owne, dost thinke I am so mad to marry, sacrifice my liberty to a Woman, sell my patromony to buy them Feathers and new fashions, and maintaine a Gentleman Vsher to ride in my saddle when I am Knighted, and pointed at with Pythagoras for my tame sufferance, ha my Wardrop laid forth and my holiday breeches, when my Lady pleases I shall take the ayre in a Coach with her, together with her Dog that is costïue, bee appointed my table what I shall eate, according as her Ladiship findes her owne body inclin'd, fed vpon this or that Melancholy dish by prescription, guarded with officious Sallets like a Prisoner in a throng, praise her beautifull allowance of course Mutton that haue the world of dainty flesh before me, 'twere a sinne of discretion and my owne freedome.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Young Mistris, I obserue you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You doe not meane to dye in this faith.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p:
Prethee doe not talke of Dying, a pox o'the Belman and his Omnia benes, but that I thinke I know thy Father, I should hardly belieue thou wert a Gentleman, howeuer
thy Aristotles of Ethicks will make thee vncapable of their company shortly, if you Catechise thus you shall have few Gentlemen your Disciples that haue any bloud or spirit about 'em, there's no discourse so becomming your Gallants now, as a Horse race or Hide-Parke? what Ladies lips are softest? what Fashion is most terse and Courtly? what newes abroad? which is, the best Vaulting house? where shall we taste Canary and be drunke too night, talke a morality— heere be Ladies still, you shall heare me court one on 'em, I hope you wee 'not report abroad among my friends that I loue her, 'tis the loue of mounting into her maydenhead I vow Iacke, and nothing else.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Y'are a mad Louer. As Aymwell comes towards Violetta she turnes and Exit.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: That was cunningly cast about.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Whither is't Lady?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I'me walking in Sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I'le wayt on you, and after that abroad, 'tis an inuiting day, are you for the Coach.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Or for the Couch? Take mee a Companion for either.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: Neither.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: How neither, blame your selfe if you be idle,
Howsoeuer you shall not be alone, make vse of
My arme Fairest, you will to your Lute, I heard you
Could touch it cunningly, pray blesse my eares a little.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: My Lute's broke sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: A string you meane, but 'tis no matter, your voyce is not, rauish a little with that, if you please I can helpe you to an heyre by this blacke eye which Nature hath giuen you, Ile not leaue you Ile follow yee. Exeunt Fowler, and Penelope.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: All this from her?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: You may belieue me Sir.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Why this to him, could shee not giue me
Repulse, but shee must thus proclaime it, I neuer
Mou'd it to her, her Vncle hath had no opportunity
To acquaint her what's the Mystery,
Prethee repeat agen the substance of what shee said.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
With my best memory her words, shee wisht you
not proceed for shee was already dispos'd of in her Fathers thoughts.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: In her fathers thoughts? Happily not in her owne.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: It would be fruitlesse to moue her Vncle or her Father in't.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Ha, not moue her Vncle or her Father?
This may beget encouragement hope I may to her
Propound my affection and be happy in't proceed.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: She would be sory a Gentleman of your worth
Should runne a Course of so much hazard.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Hazard, that word does yet imply there is a possibilitie.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: So with complement
Of her thankes for your fayre opinion of her,
Shee wisht me make you sensible in time
To place your Loue where you might expect
Better returne.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Ah that's wormwood, let me see, better returne
This last returne hath spoyl'd the whole Terme
And vndone my suite, vm? No it doth admit
A faire Construction:
Shee would ha me sensible in time to plant
My loue where I may expect better returne,
Why? That I may from her for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Amantes sibi somnia fingunt, how apt are Louers to conster all to their desires.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: I wonnot let my Action fall.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Doe not build Castles.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: I'le smooth it with her Vncle, if it hit
Oh I my blest Starres.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Hee's a bed already.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Venus assist one to thy Altar flies,
And I'le proclaime, thy sonne hath found his eyes. Exeunt.

div.head: Scena, I.
div.stage: Enter Sir Nicholas Treedle, and a Servant.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: WHere's Marre-text my Chaplaine.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: He's newly walked out of his Meditation in the Kitchin, into the Garden.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Bid him reade Prayers in the Dining-roome.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Before your Worship come?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I wo'not pray too day, dost heere? Bid my Tutor come downe to mee.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Which on them.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Why hee that reades Trauaile to me, the wit that I tooke vp in Paules in a tiffany Cloake without a hatband, now I haue put him into a doublet of Sattaine— stay hee's heere. Enter Tutor.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Morrow Tutor, what houre take you it?

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: It is no houre at all Sir.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Not directly any houre, for it is betweene 8. and 9. Sir.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Very learnedly then I was ready betweene Six and seauens too day.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Are you dispos'd for Lecture.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Yes, yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.l: You remember my last prelection of the Diuision
Of the Earth into parts Reall and Imaginary:
The parts reall into Continent and Iland,
The subdiuision of the Continent, into Peninsula,
Istmus, and Promontory.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: In troth Sir, I remember some such things but I haue forgotten 'em.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: What is an Istmus?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Why an Istmus, is an Elbow of land.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: A Necke, a necke.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: A necke? Why I was neere it, if you had let me alone, I should haue come vp too't.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: 'Twas well guest, what's an Iland?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: An Iland is an high Mountaine, which shooteth it selfe into the Sea.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: That's a Promontory.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Is't so? An Iland then is, no matter let it goe, 'tis not the first Iland wee ha lost.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: How are you perfect in your Circles? Great & lesse, Mutable and immutable, Tropicall and Polar.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: As perfect in them as I am in these, faith I shall neuer conne these things handsomely, may not a man study Trauaile without these Circles, Degrees and altilatitudes you speake of?

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Yes, you may.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I doe not care for the neerest way, I ha time enough to goe about.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Very well, you shall lay aside your Globe then.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I, and if please you I will haue it stand in my hall to make my Tenants wonder instead of the book of Martyrs.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: It will doe well, now name what Kingdome or Prouince you haue most minde to.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: What say you to England.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: By no meanes, it is not in fashion with Gentlemen to study their owne Nation, you will discouer a dull easinesse if you admire not and with admiration preferre not the weedes of other regiments before the most pleasant flowers of your owne garden, let your Iudgment reflect vpon a serious consideration who teaches you the minick posture of your body, the punctuality of your beard, the formality of your pace, the elbowes of your cloake, the heele of your boote, doe not other nations? Are not Italian heads Spanish shoulders, Dutch bellies, and French legs, the onely Notions of your reformed English Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I am resolu'd to be ignorant of my owne country say no more on't, what think you if I went ouer to France the first thing I did.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: By Sea.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Dee thinke I ha no more wit then to venture my selfe i'th salt water, I had rather be pickled and powdred at home by halfe that I had.

sp.speaker: Tu
sp.p: I apprehend you are cautious, it is safe trauelling in your study, but I will not read France to you.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Pardonne moy it is vnnecessary, all the French fashions are here already or rather your French cuts.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Cuts?

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Vnderstand me, there are diuers French cuts.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: We haue had too many French cuts already.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: First, there is your cut of the head.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: That's dangerous.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Pshew a haire a hayre, a perriwigge is your French cutte and in fashion with your most courtly Gallants, your owne hayre will naturally forsake you.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: A bald reason.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Right obseru'd their prudent and weighty pollicy who haue brought up this artificiall head-peice, because no man should appeare light headed.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: He had no sound head that inuented it.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Then there is the new cut of your doublet or slash the Fashion of your apparrell a queint cut.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Vpon Taffety.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Or what you please, the slash is the embleme of your valour, and besides declareth that you are open brested.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Open as much as you will but no valour.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Then Sir, there is the cut of your leg.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: That's when a man is drunke, is it not?

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Doe not stagger in your iudgement, for this cut is the grace of your body, I meane dancing o'th French cut i'th leg is most fashionable, beleeue it pupill a gentile carriage.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: But it is faine to be supported sometime with a bottome. Enter Seruant.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Here is Sir George Richley Sir newly alighted.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh my Father in law that shalbe.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Then wee are cut off.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: There is a match concluded between his daughter and me and now he comes for my answere conduct him to the gallery.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Rather Sir meete him.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Let him goe before and tell him we are comming and weele be there as soone as hee. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Braynes.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: What's the matter.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Lets rifle the other bottle of wine.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Doe not indanger thy sconce.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I'le drink no more.

sp.speaker: Whib.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Because I will not be drunke for any mans pleasure.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Drunke?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Tis good English now, t'was Dutch, may bee you ha some conspiracy vpon mee.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: I? Who has betrayed me? his Mistris procured the Key of the Wine-seller, and bad me try if I could wind vp his braines handsomely, he knowes on't not one health more.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Not, not, good Whible if you vrge agen I shall suspect.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: Suspect me?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: And beate you Whible if you be not satisfied.

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: I am, but in friendship.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Dost tempt me?

sp.speaker: Wh.
sp.p: I will drinke your health and be drunke alone.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p:
This whelpe has some plot vpon men, I smell powder my young Mistris would haue blowne vp my braines this Peter-gunner should haue given fire, 'tis not the first time shee hath conspired so but two not doe, I was neuer yet couzned in my life, and if I pawne my braines for a bottle of Sacke, or Claret, may my nose as a brand for my negligence carry euerlasting Malmesey in it, and be studded with Rubies and Carbuncles, Mistris you must pardon my officiousnesse, be as angry as a Tyger I must play the Dragon and watch your golden fleece, my Master has put me in trust and I am not so easily corrupted. I ha but two eyes Argus had a hundred, but hee must be a cunning Mercury must pipe them both a sleepe I can tell you. And now I talke of sleepe, my lodging is next to her chambers, it is a confidence in my Master to let his Liuery lye so neere her, Seruingmen haue e're now proved themselues no Eunuches, with their Masters Daughters, if I were so lusty as some of my owne tribe, it were no great labour to commit Burglary vpon a Mayden head, but all my nourishment runs vpward into braines and I am glad on't, a temperate blood is signe of a good Liver, I am past tilting, here shee is with the second part of her to the same tune, an other maide that has a grudging
of the greene sicknes. and wants a man to recouer her.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Be this enough betweene vs to bind each to helpe others designes.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Heeres Breynes, hee has not yet beene drencht.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: Hee is too subtile.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: How now Breynes?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: As you see forsooth.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Thou art very sad.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: But I am in sober sadnes I thanke my starres.

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.p: Witty.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: As much wit as will keepe Breynes from melting this hot weather.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: A dry whooresone not thus to be wrought vpon!

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Very good Sacke and Claret ith house.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Thou hast not tasted.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Oyes, oyes, my braines swimme in Canary, exceedingly excellent Sacke I thanke yee Ladies, I know tis your pleasure I should not want o'th best blood o'th grape in hope there might be a stone in my cup to marre my drinking afterwards. Enter Sensible.
Mistris Sensible what igge ithe wind shee moues so nimbly.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: From whom?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Master Fowler.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: A Letter? whence flew that paper kite.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: What this?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: An other inclosed without direction happily obserued.

sp.speaker: Pen,
sp.p: If you can loue I will study to deserue and be happy to giue you proofe of my service, in the meane time it shalbe a testimony of your favour to deliuer this inclosed paper to your couzen from her servant Aymwell, farewell and remember Fowler, looke you couzen what Mr. Fowler writes, I dare trust you with the secret at your opportunity peruse this paper.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p:
Conveyances, I read iugling in that paper already, and though you put it vp I wo not oh, for so much Magick to coniure that paper out of her bosome into my pocket now I doe long to know what pittifull louer for it
can be no other, is doing penance in that white sheete already, Mistris Sensible harke yee; whence came that letter?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: From Master Fowler to my Mistris.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: It is a shee Letter it seemes.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: A shee Letter why so?

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Because it had a young one it'h belly on't, or I am much mistaken.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Does he not write like a bold gamester?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: And a bowling gamester too, for his byas was towards my Mistres, but I may chance to cast a rub in his way to keepe him from kissing.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Hee hath very good partes in him questionlesse, but doe you loue him.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: O the cunning of these Gipses, how when they list they can talke in a distinguishable dialect, they call men foxes but they make, tame geese a some on vs, and yet like one a those in Rome I may prove so happy to preserue your distressed Capitoll, what newes brings this Kickshaw.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Master Fowler desires to speake with you.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Already he might ha deliuered his owne Letter.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ile to my Chamber

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: It will doe very well.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I hope you wilbe carefull that I am not troubled with any visit of Gentlemen, it will become your officiousnesse good Dametas to haue a care of your charge Pamela.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: So, I can suffer this jeare. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Ha? is he gone? I'me glad on't, Ile take this opportunity to reade the Paper, Master Aymwell sent me no superscription?

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Shee's at it already, thus farre of I can read her countenance if she spare her voyce.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I doe not court your fortune but your loue,
If my wild apprehension of it, proue
My error, punish gently, since the fire
Came from your selfe that kindled my desire.
So my poore heart full of expectance lyes
To be your seruant or your sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: It shall bee answered. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: It shall, the games a foote, were I best to discouer thus much, or reserue it to welcome home the old Knight withall, Ile be more familiar with this iugling, first, the Scriuener has a Name and if he be worth his owne eares he shall be worth my discouery.
Here comes the Gallant and the tother toy now.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I receiued your Letter Sir?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: In good time.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: You might haue spared your hand a labour, if you had resolved to put your feete vpon this expedition.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I confesse I wrote something in my owne cause, but the chiefe cause was to convay my friends affection to his Mistris.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: And I will convey your affection to somebody else.

sp.speaker: Pen
sp.p: Then you made me a property. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: 'Tis for your honour if you helpe any way to aduance an honest businesse, and yet mistake me not though the Racke should enforce from me without a second reason I had not wrote to you, yet for so much as concern'd my selfe by this kisse, my pen hath but set downe the resolution of my heart to serue you.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: To serue me, how?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: How? why any way, giue me your Liuery I'le weare it, or a Coate with a Cognizance by this light, I feare you are an Hereticke still and doe not beleeue as you should doe, come let me rectifie your Faith, serue you.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Since the Complement of Service came up, Gentlemen have had excuse for their love: I would not have you serve me Sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Not serve you? Why dee thinke a man cannot love and serve too.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Not one serve two, well.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: You are too literall, and yet i'th strict sence I ha knowne a woman has served halfe a doozen Gentlemen handsomely, so, so, and yet the last had enough of her too, why should not one man serve two Gentlewomen, it argues against your Sexe, that you are more insatiable ath' two, but I have a simple affection I protest and individuall, Ile neere serve but one.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: But one at once.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: But one at once, and but one alwayes, by this Dyamond.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: Nay keepe your oath Sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I am forsworne if I doe not, for I vowed before I came to bestow it, come weare it in your bosome, it shall be an earnest of more precious jewels, though not of so bright a lustie that will follow.

sp.speaker: Penel.
sp.p: I pray Sir resolve me one thing, and be plaine, Doe you love me?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Love you?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: 'Tis my question.

sp.speaker: Fow,
sp.p: 'Tis a very foolish one, to what purpose have I beene talking all this while, that you make it a question, has not it beene the Theame of all my discourse hitherto, that I doe love you.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: In what sence?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: In what sence? Why in any sence at your owne choyce, or in all the sences together and you doubt me: I doe love to see your face, heare your voyce, smell your breath, touch your tree, and taste your golden Apples.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: But this does not satisfie me.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: You doe not doubt my sufficiency dee?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Now you're immodest, I onely askt if you love me.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: And ha not I told you? Pray teach me a better way to expresse it. Does a Wiseman love Fooles fortune, and a Nobleman another beside my Lady? Does the Divell love an Vsurer, a Great man his Flatterer, the Lawyer a Full Terme, or the Physitian a dead time to thrive in.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Spare your selfe this is but course love.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p:
Ile spin it finer and finer every day Sweet, to be
plaine with thee, what dost thou think of me for a husband, I love thee that way.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Would you did else.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Is there my thing in me would commend it selfe, that I may spare my other commendations, for I am resolved to be yours at any rate of my own praise, or what I can purchase from my friends.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Sir, if your meaning be no stranger to your language, although I cannot promise my selfe, you bind me to bee thankfull for it.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: She nibbles already.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: But pardon me if I suspect you still, you are too wild and aery to be constant to that affection.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: There be the Pigeons.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: An't be no worse I care not, Mr. Fowler
A most welcome Friend.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I would be to your daughter.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Let her use to entertaine him so, and hee'l bid himselfe welcome, harke you sir, you doe like his company?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: So I say, but if I were worthy to give your daughter counsell she should have a speciall care how she treads, for if this Gentleman be not a Whooremaster, he is very like one; and if she chance any way to cracke her Venice-Glasse, 'twill not be so easily sowdred.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Meddle with your charge Sir, and let her alone.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I have done, here is a fresh Gamester. Enter Mr. Manley.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: By your noble leave.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: You'r welcome Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I was directed hither to find a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Manly how ist?

sp.speaker: Manl.
sp.p: I was to inquire for you at your lodging.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Pray know this gentleman Lady Master Worthy heele deserue your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You oblige my seruices— but what make you heere my woman ferritor.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Come hither Penelope.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Solliciting a cause of Venus.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I suspect as much, but with her? is shee a whoore?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: No but I'le doe the best to make her one,
She loues me already, that's some engagement
I dare trust thee with my sinnes, who's heere
Aymwell and Clare. Enter Mr. Aymwell, Mr. Clare, Braines.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Withdraw your selfe.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Franck.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Master Worthy.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: A knot of friends.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: What of my letter?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: 'Tis deliuered you must expect.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: What newes gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: We heare none, you visit the Exchange Sir, pray furnish vs.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: What doe all these Butterflies here, I doe not like it.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: I hope your daughter is in health.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Perfect, I thanke Heauen.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: And your Neece at whose naming I'me bolde to tender my thankes for your last friendship, I might haue plung'd by this time into passion had not you nobly, iust as I was falling preuented my vnhappinesse.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Your opinion of what I did, giues value to the action, howeuer 'twas a duty I was bound to.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: This is the youth, I'le pawne my braines, harke you Sir, what doe you call this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Master Aymwell.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: He may shoote short for all his ayming,
He weares Batchellers buttons does he not.

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: Yes, old trupeny and loopes too, thou art iealous now.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: One word more.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I haue a plot and thou must helpe me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Let it be a safe one.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: May we not see her?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Braines where's thy Mistris?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: She's a little busie.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Who's that.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: my Neece.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: And shee be but a little busy shee's more then halfe at leasure.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
Doe not you know that a Woman is more troubled
with a little businesse, then some man with mannaging the troubles of a whole common wealth, it has beene a prouerbe, as busy as a Hen with one Chickin, marry and shee had twenty, twenty to one she would not be so fond on'em.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: He sayes right, Gentlemen, wee are friends, it is my brothers pleasure who is her father, to deny frequent accesse to her, till hee hath finisht a designe, for my part, I am not of his minde, nor shall my daughter be a prisoner to his fancy, you see Sir I doe not seclude her, if shee chuse within any limits of reason, I moue in her.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: You speake nobly.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Sir George Richley Sir, and Sir Nicholas are newly arriu'd.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: My brother, acquaint my Neece.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: T'is my office I'le doe it— Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Shall's stay?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: By all meanes let's see the doughty Knight that must free the Lady from her Inchaunted Castle.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Didst euer see him?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: No, but I haue heard his character.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Prethee let's ha't.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p:
They say hee's one, was wise before hee was a man for then his folly was excuseable, but since hee came to be of age, which had beene a question till his death, had not the Law giuen him his Fathers Lands, he is growen wicked enough to be a Landlord, he does pray but once a yeare and that's for faire weather in haruest, his inward sences are sound, for none comes from him hee speakes wordes but no matter, and therefore is in Election to be of the Peace and Quorum, which his Tenants thinke him fit for, and his Tutors iudgement allowes, whom he maintaines to make him legs and speeches, he feedes well himselfe, but in obedience to government, he allowes his Servants fasting dayes; he loves Law, because it kild his Father, whom the
Parson overthrew in a case of Tithes; and in memory, wears nothing sutable, for his Apparell is a or the ruines of ten fashions, he does not much care for Heaven, for he's doubtfull of any such place, onely Hell he's sure of, for the Divell stickes to his Conscience, therefore he does purpose when he dyes, to turne his sinnes into Almeshouses, that posterity may praise him for his bountifull of hot Pottage, but he's here already, you may reade the rest as he comes towards you. Enter Sir George, Sir Nicholas, Tut.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Brother.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Let your kindest respects meet this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Sir Nicholas Treedle, I desire you would write me in the number of your Servants.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: 'Tis granted, Gentlemen I have an ambition to be your eternall slave.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: 'Tis granted.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: And I to be an everlasting Rascall.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: 'Tis granted.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: A couple of Cockaloches.

div.stage: Enter Penelope, Violetta, Winifred, Sensible, and Breines.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Here comes my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Lady and Mistris of my heart, which hath long melted for you.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: This is my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Then it melted for you Lady.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: His heart is whole againe.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Vouchsafe to entertaine a Servant, that shall study to command.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Well sayd.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: His extreamest possibilities— in your businesse.

sp.speaker: Aymw.
sp.p: Abhominable Courtship.

sp.speaker: Sens.
sp.p: Sir, I am Servant to Mistris Violetta, who commends this Paper to you.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: O my best Angell.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: As the Divell would have it, are you there Sensible.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Mr. Worthy I take my leaue.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Will you not stay supper.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Wee are engaged.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: My service shall waite on you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Clare
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come on my Queene of Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Master Worthy I take my leaue.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Will you not stay supper.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: We are engaged.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: My seruice shall waite on you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And mine.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come on my Queene of Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Brother lead the way. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: If shee carry away this letter so, call me shallow-braines, I was neuer yet couzen'd in my life, this night? it shall be so, I will not come with bare relation of your plots,
sp.l: Ile bring active intelligence that shall tell
Your secret aymes, so crush 'em in the shell.

div.head: Scena, I.
div.stage: While the Musicke is playing enter Breynes without his shooes with a Letter in his band.

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: SVre this is it, my Mistris and her maide are both fast still, I ha watched vnder the bed all night, to rob her pocket of this paper, and I ha don't, some fellow at this opportunity would haue wrigled himselfe into one of their flesh.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Who's there? Sensible.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Death her tongue is awake already.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Who's i'the chamber.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Helpe me Breynes, before shee wakes the tother, 'tis I forsooth but looking for the chamberpot. Counterfeits Sensibles voyce.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Beshrew you for your noyse.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Where's the doore— stumbles.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: The tother spirit is rais'd i'th Trundlebed
What will become o'me now. Enter Sensible.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Here's no body.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Make an end and get thee to bed.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: An end of what, does she talke in her sleepe, shee was not wont.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.l: So, so, ha the spring is open
I might forget to make it fast last night,
'Tis so, and happily some Curre or Cat
Has beene i'the chamber, for I heare a noyse
About the doore, I'le make it fast
And so to bed againe, I thinke it is day already. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Tutor in his gowne as from his study.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.l: So this fancy wrote, for Sir Nicholas like a forked
Arrow points two wayes, wenches are caught with
Such conceipts, they will imagin't none of his
Inuention, then whose but mine my person does inuite
More acceptation, but the Father aymes
At the estate, no matter if I can
Insinuate my selfe into her opinion
'Tis no impossibility, her portion
Will be enough for both, shall I liue still
Dependant and not seeke wayes to aduance my
Selfe, busy my braines in ballads to the giddy
Chambermaides, begger my selfe with purse and pincase
When shee that is the Mistris may be mine
T'will be a Master piece if I can gull him,
But he's here already. Enter Sir Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Noble Tutor, Morrow to you, hay finished
The whimzey for my Mistris already?

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: I ha don't, this paper carries the Loue powder.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: For feare you had forgotten me, I ha made a quibling in praise of her my selfe, such a one as will fetch vp her heart Tutor.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: That were a dangerous vomit Sir, take heed of that.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I but I will not hurt her I warrant thee, and shee dy within a Twelue month and a day Ile be hangd for her.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Will you Sir.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Marry will I, looke you Sir. But first let me see yours, can you not write it in my owne hand, I shall hardly read it.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: I'le reade it to you.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Sir George G'ee mee't.

div.stage: Enter Sir George, and M. Worthy.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: See they are at it.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: And how doe you like it.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Morrow noble Sir Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Morrow Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Morrow to you both, Sir George I ha been making Poetry this morning.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: He has a subtile fancy.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: What's the subiect?

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: No subiect, but the Queene of his affections.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I scorne subiects, 'tis my Empresse your Daughters Muse hath set my muse on fire.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Reade Sir.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No, you shall read 'em for me.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: 'Tis a hue and cry Sir.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: A hue & cry, for what?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: For what, why for somewhat I'le warrant you.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: You may call it Loues hue and cry.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Call it what you will, I know what 'tis.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Are you so Poeticall.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I ha beene dabling in Helicon, next to trauaile 'tis all my study marke the inuention.

lg.l: In Loves name you are charg'd hereby
To make a speedy hue and cry,
After a face who tother day
Came and stole my heart away;
For your directions in briefe
These are best markes to know the thiefe:
Her hayre a net of beames would prove,
Strong enough to Captive Iove:
Playing the Eagle, her cleere brow
Is a comely field of snow,
A sparkling Eye, so pure a gray
As when it shines it needs no day:
Ivory dwelleth on her nose
Lilly married to the rose,
Have made her Cheeke the nuptiall bed
Lippes betray their Virgins weed
As they onely blusht for this
That they one another kisse,
But observe beside the rest
You shall know this fellon best
By her Tongue, for if your Eare
Shall once a heavenly Musicke heare
Such as neither Gods nor men
But from that voyce shall heare, agen
That that is shee, Oh take her t'ee
None can rocke heaven asleepe but shee.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: How doe you like my pipin of Pernassus Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ric. Wor.
sp.p: Very handsome.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Na, I'le warrant you, my Tutor has good furniture in him.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I doe not thinke hee made 'em.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Now you shall heare some verses of my owne making.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Your owne, did you not make these?

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: He betrayes himselfe.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Hum? yes I made 'em too my Tutor knowes.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: I'le take my oath who made e'm.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: But I wrote 'em for an other gentleman that had a Mistris.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: My daughter you said.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I may say so, but that their faces are nothing alike, you would hardly know one from tother, for your better vnderstanding I will read 'em my selfe— Her foote.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Dee begin there?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Oh, I will rise by degrees.
Her foote is feat with Dyamond toes
But shee with legs of Ruby goes:
Thighes Loadstones, and doe draw vnto her
The Iron pinne of any wooer.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Pretious conceit.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Her head.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Her head?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: You were betweene her thighes but now.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: T'is my conceit, I doe now meane to goe downewards agen, and meete where I left in the middle.

lg.l: Her head is Opall, necke of Saphyre,
Breast Carbuncles, shine like a fire.
And the naked truth to tell you,
The very mother of Pearle her belly:
How can shee chose but heare my groanes,
That is composed of precious stones.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: I marry Sir.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Now if you lik't you may.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: A word with you Sir, pray what dee thinke of your pupill.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: I thinke nothing Sir.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: But deale ingeniously, your opinion.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Shall I tell you?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: Pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: I thinke so too, what doth my Brother meane to make this fond Election.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: For my owne part you heare me say nothing, but the good parts and qualities of men are to be valued.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: This fellow's a Knaue, I smell him.

sp.speaker: Tu
sp.p: Some thing has some sauour.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: When you please, name your owne time
I'me ready to be married at midnight.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: About a seavennight hence.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Let it be 3. or 4. I care not how soone, is breakefast ready.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: It waites vpon you.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I doe loue to eate and drinke in a morning, though I fast all day after.

sp.speaker: Ric.
sp.p: Ile follow brother.

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: Wee'le both attend. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Aymwell with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: This opportunity, let my couetous eye,
Take to enrich it selfe, but first prepare
With reuerence, as to an Alter bring
No carelesse but Religious beames along
With you to this new obiect, this small paper
Carries the volume of my humane fate
I hold my destiny, betwixt two fingers
And thus am I wrapt vp without a name
Being or expectation of worlds ioy
More then this table (when the curtaines drawne)
Presents in Character to my thirsty eye sight,
Hayle thou embassadour from thine and my
Mistris, bringing peace or vnkind warre
Thou Embleme of her whitenesse which I kisse
And thus againe salute. Enter Boy and Clare.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Then hee's alone.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: So leaue vs.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Comming from her
Can it be guilty of defiance to me
Had shee not meant me happy shee had giuen
My letter to the flame, and with it I
In those thinne ashes had beene buried,
Nor had shee dain'd this answere with the circumstance
At my receiuing prompts mee to beleeue
Gratious the gentle messenger command it
Not as a thing shee woo'd a publique, but
With eyes full of suspition which had beene
Needlesse, had shee contemn'd my seruice.
So smilingly departed, Thus I sent my paper
Which what but loue taught her to imitate
Without a superscription, Oh Clare welcome,
Welcome to that heart daunce i'thy bosome
If thou beest a friend and canst reioyce to know mee
Happie, you thought me ridiculous and that I did
With too much flattery of my selfe, expound your story
Had I beene like thee of Frosty apprehension and cold
Phlegmaticke iudgement, I had mist a blessing
That wanton Iove would haue beene Riuall for
Dost see this paper?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nothing in the outside.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: T'is inly pretious.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You haue not searcht the
Lining that you promise so.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: I see through it, hast thou not heard the perfect Magnes
Will although inclos'd within an Iuory box,
Through the white wall shoote forth embracing vertue
To the lou'd needle, I can read it Clare
And reade a Ioy in't that transports me, this
Came from my Mistris, hauing touch'd her hand
Whence it receiu'd a whitenesse hath it not
Brought incense to dipersing a rich breath
Sweeter then Arabian spicery
About the roome, in which while it remaines
Wee sucke in perfum'd ayre, it came from her
My honest Clare, from her she whose rare wit taught
When in thy dull opinion I was lost,
My apprehension a new hope to thriue
In my ambitious loue, excellent women
The top of all creation I shall bee
At once too happy, vnrip thou the seale
Read it, and let thy voyce conuey it gently
Least I be surfetted, but why should any
Be honoured to receiue her
But I, to whom shee hath directed it,
By thy leaue silent paper, confident
Of blesse I open my Elizeum
And let my soule into it— ha. Reades
Laden with mighty hopes how dispendant
Haue I launched forth and finde a storme.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What's this? Your owne Letter returned
Can it be otherwise then in scorne.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: In scorne.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Ha you not now cause of tryumph, who is now the truer Prophet, you would nourish hope in spight of reason, now you feele a punishment in her derision.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Is this credible.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Credible? 'Tis no wonder in a woman
Though shee had promised, vowed affection to you
It had not beene a miracle to find
A Change in their affection, yet you cannot
Accuse her much.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Appear'd I so vnworthy
That 'mong so many wayes she had to expresse
At what poore value shee esteemed my proffered
Seruice, her pride could finde out none but this
To send me mine owne agen.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Doe but imagine
You sent a servant with a message to her,
Shee not within, he is return'd agen
Without an answere.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Inciuility,
Shee might haue thank'd me, and subscrib'd her name,
I was not bound to her obseruance.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Come be free againe.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: I will be so, with this
That I could cancell my affection.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What doe you meane, it hauing touch'd her hand
Is full of incence and Arabian spicery
You are too prodigall of your perfume.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Doe not thou mocke me too.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Well, I ha done.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Would I had so I cannot empty all
My torment, wherefore should a man loue woman
Such aery mockeries, nothing but meere Ecchoes
That owe theyr being to our opinion
And in reward of honouring them, send backe
As scornefully the language we bestowed.
Out of our too much dotage.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: If they send,
All they receiue from vs, accuse them not
We haue our hearts againe.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: And Ile haue mine,
I will, I ha not yet, here wants a guest
Inuite him home againe, Why should not I
Be as coy as shee, and with as much neglect
Throw her behind my thoughts, instruct me with
Witty reuenge, and thou that see me tosse
This shuttlecocke with as much pride, and when
I'me sated with this sport, let fall this vanity
Into as low disdaine, pshew.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Nobly resolu'd.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Come to a Tauerne, drench the memory
Of these poore thoughts.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Let's seeke out Master
Fowler and Manly.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: And warm'd with sacke, wee'l try
Who can make Satyres best.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: A match, lets to 'em.

div.stage: Enter Master Fowler, Manly like his Phisitian.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: And thou dost not play the Doctor handsomely, Il'e set the Colledge of Phisitians vpon thee for practising without a licence.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Can you bee sicke?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I would but counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So must I the Phisitian.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I haue knowne a spruse Empericke hath given his patient 2 or 3. stooles with the bare repetition of crude wordes, and knotty sentences, which haue come from him like a Phlegme, which besides the operation in the hearers, who admire him for't, while he beates like a drumme, at their barrell head, and turnes their braines like beere, does him the benefit to scowre his owne durty maw, whose dregs else would putrifie; and infest his cheekes worse then a gangreene.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Are you sure shee will visit you?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: As sure as I am well, for and I were sicke and would sleepe, I would rather, take a nap o'th ridge of Etna, and thee fall of deafning Nilus, then indure the visitation, of any of their tribe— one knockes, my pillow and lay my head in the aking posture. One knocks

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Tis Aymwell and Clare.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Where's my witty Bacchanalian, how now? what meanes this Apothecaries shop about thee, art Physicall?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Sicke, sicke.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Didst not looke in a glasse to day? how scuruely this nightcap shewes vpon thee.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What's the disease?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: A feauer Sir.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Hang feauers, let's to the Tauerne, and inflame our selues, with lusty wine, sucke in the spirit of Sacke, till wee bee Delphicke and prophecie my bully rooke.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Alas.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Alasse, is that the disease, Drench her, drench her in sack, sicke for a lasse, doe not foole thy selfe beyond the cure of Bedlam, be wise and well agen.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: You are merry, it seemes you haue won the Lady.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p:
What Lady? the Lady ith' Lobster, I was halfe
sicke for foolish thing called a woman, a toy tooke mee i'th head, and had like to haue taken away my heart too but I ha recouered, doe not trust thy body with a Phisitian, heele make thy foolish bones goe without flesh in a fortnight, and thy soule walke without a body a seauen night after.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: These are no Doctors?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Doctor! art a Parisian, a Paduan, or a Leaden Doctor?
How many and be true to vs hast thou kild the last
Spring, will it puzzel thy arithmeticke, my pretious
Rectifier of nature, the wrong way,— faith
Thou must excuse me Iacke that I cannot condole
With thee, by this whay beard of Esculapius, I dare
Not endanger my selfe with so much mellancholly
Least I fall into a relapse— whom haue wee heere?

sp.speaker: Wo.
sp.p: T'is reported that Master Fowler is sick and keepes his chamber, I hope hee's within.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Fayre Lady.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: How fare you Sir?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: The better to see you heere.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Vpon the entrance of this Gentlewoman, I finde your griefe much altered.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Vpon mine?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, and by that I dare presume to say you are the cause of his distemper.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I Sir?

sp.speaker: Pow.
sp.p: A cunning Doctor

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: For I obserud so soone as his searching eye had fastned on her, his labouring pulse that through his Feauor did, before sticke hard, and frequent now exceeds in both these differences and this Gallen himselfe found true vpon a woman, that had doted vppon a Fencer.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.l: Shee did long for tother bout then,

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Giue vs leaue pray.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: A very pretty fellow,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Well skild i'th pulse.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: You know my disease too dee not? will not my complexion giue you the hint on't

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You are not very well.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: By your fauour you will come too't.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: To what?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To a burning Feauor— is there not one woman in the world.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: I thinke there is, and too much of that, what then what conclude you?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nothing but Sirrup of Violet, would comfort you going to bed.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Violet?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Has giuen't you.

sp.speaker: Fow:
sp.p: It does me good Lady to feele you by— the hand.

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: Would it were in my power to recouer you.

sp.speaker: Fow:
sp.p: The Doctor I thanke him has taken paines with me, but he sayes— nothing will doe me good.

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: Nothing?

sp.speaker: Fow:
sp.p: But that, which is another sicknesse to reueale.

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: Pray Sir acquaint me.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I know you loue me.
I haue a great mind and 'twere but for two or 3. Minutes, to haue a maide warme my bed.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: That may be done.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: With her body— else t'will doe me no good the Doctor sayes— to put life in some of my limbes, a little virgin warm'th wo'd doo't.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: You haue a burning Feauor.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: But now and then I haue such cold fits againe— and t'is the Doctors opinion— a very learned man.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: A learned Pandor.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: He's at it.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cla..
sp.p: Againe passionate.

sp.speaker: Aym:
sp.p: Why, I may loue her name without offence, to you, why did hee waken my remembrance I had forgotten her.

sp.speaker: Cla:
sp.p: Thinke vpon her scorne then.

sp.speaker: Aym:
sp.p: I ha done, and till I heare her name agen I will throw this dulnesse off.

sp.speaker: Cla:
sp.p: Lets choose another subiect
How closely they consult, the Doctor is in a fit of counsell I suspect some iugling— hee comes of, Ile gage a limbe this fellowe's an impostor.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Is there not much danger in him?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Within two minutes Gentlemen, I haue discovered happier symptomes.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: So Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The redundant chollerick matter.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Tis no matter Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I thinke you doe not loue him.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Pursue it.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: What shall I gee to poyson him?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Would he were in Heauen, de'e like well of this complexion.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: It shall hire me to kill your Father

lg.l: To shew how much I valew sir your life
For I beleeue you doe not mocke, soone as
Your strength will giue you leaue to visit me
At my Fathers house, where I can command
An opportunity, my true loue shall
Present you with your wishes, my maid onely.
Shall be of councell to admit you, but
You'le make me satisfaction by marriage.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: At a minutes warning.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: One thing more, ere I giue vp my honour, I will haue your oath no other woman hath enioy'd your person.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Willingly, 'las I could neere be tempted, and but that there is a kind of necessity.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Be confident of my best loue.

lg.l: Seale it now,
I feele my spirits gather force already,
My blood shake off the corrupt humour, ha?
What an I goe home we'e Lady?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Y'are pretty well already, then you may excuse our meeting.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Ho, no, no, we are all apt to flatter our selves, farewell sweet Lady,—— if I liue I'le see you, if I dye——

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Whible——

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: At hand and foote to doe you service.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: You will poyson him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: He is dead, as you find me in this, let me ha your custome.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: You quick salving Rogue.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Doe, bee valiant.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: A stratagem my noble Tully, a stratagem, shee's my owne, the castle of comfort is yielding vp, I see it prostrate already, my valiant Engineere.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: The old humour; now has he the promise of some Maydenhead.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: The beleeuing Creature could not hold out.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: If you thriue so well in your wench, I am no company for you.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Not for me, Ile worry thee Franck to death, if thou flinchest, to the Oracle boyes, thou shouldst hunt as I doe these wanton Rabbet suckers, come wee'l haue thy story in Apollo, now my owne tales over,—— I'le busy my breines to set thy wheels in a handsome motion agen, be bold as I am, let no denyall, make thee remoue thy siege, they must come to parly, make but wise conditions, and the Forts thine owne I warrant thee, come to the Oracle.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Cracke my sides with laughter, heere's a purchase happier then I expected, her owne Letter to Aymwell, his (which was the most I could hope for) would haue beene but presumption, this is euidence against the world, to this haue I added seale and superscription to the old Knight my Master, oh how I could hug my selfe with the thought on't, they may talke of womens wit, 'tis as slender as their apronstrings from whence they fetch it, they haue no reaches in 'em, here comes my Mistris moueable. Enter Sensible .She shall doe the seate Mistris Sensible, here's a Letter to my Master, I am going in some hast to dispatch some businesse, when he comes, at opportunity doe so much as deliuer it, woo't.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: A greater curtesy then this for you.

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Oh that I were a Youth of one and twenty againe.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Bre.
sp.p: Heare my wish out, and ten thousand pounds in a musty Coffer, a house well furnished, Acres enough of my own about it, 50. ploughs a going, 20. horse in the stable, beside a Caroach& 6. Flanders Mares 10. tall knaues in liuerie, 8. veluet Pages, 6. Footmen in Cadis. I would marry thee, loue thee, lye with thee, and get so many braines without sage, as should furnish any nation in Christendome, with politicians girle, farewell sweet, kind Sensible.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: What crotchets be these, the fellowes mad I thinke.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.l: Oh looke Sensible seeke euery where
About the chamber, I ha lost the letter
Aymwell sent me, if we should be
Discouer'd, we are quite vndone, whats that in thy hand,

sp.speaker: Sen:
sp.p: A letter.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.p: Whence.

sp.speaker: Sen:
sp.p: I know not t'was left heere, and Breines hauing some businesse to dispatch requested me to deliuer it.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.p: Let me see't. To the right worshipfull Sir George Richly, I see him comming, loose no time, employ thy diligence to search for mine, I will deliuer this.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: I shall Mistris.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.l: My father presses me to marry Treedle
Short time's allowed for the preuention Enter Sir Geo.
My good angell assist me, here's a letter Sir.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Whence.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I know not, your seruant Breines receiued it.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: What's here— daughter doe not you know whence this letter came?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Not I Sir.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: You cannot bee so ignorant.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: What meanes my father?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: You are familiar with the Contents.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I beseech you Sir haue no suspition.—

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I'le read it to you, Mr. Aymwell; I receiued your letter, and praise your apprehension, vpon the first view of your person, I conceiu'd opinion of your merit, the flame is now too great to bee supprest, it is no time to protract your hopes nor dishonour in mee to yeild vpon noble conditions at the first summon, I accept your loue, and require your industry to preuent my fathers purpose, my seruant Sensible you may trust, I will vse some inuention to delay my expected marriage, farewell.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My harsh fate.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: De'e know this charracter, where's my man Braines.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Your man deuill. Enter Braines.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Did your worship call?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Oh my best seruant.
Does not thy very soule blush to deceiue me.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: What's the matter Mistris.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.p: Here me I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.l: I'th height and puzze of my care to make
Thee, happie? to conspire thy ouerthrow
I wo'not heare.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: This was your worke you can read.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: And write too the superscription of a Letter or so.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Where's Sensible Enter Sensible.
For your good seruice to your Mistris housewife
Packe vp your trinckets, I here discharge you.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: I hope you are Sensible.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.p: Oh wench my father hath my letter.

sp.speaker: Sen:
sp.p: Yours?

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.p: And I mistaking seal'd and return'd Aymwell that which he sent.

sp.speaker: Sen:
sp.p: How came he by't.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.p: Talke not of that, Oh for some art to helpe vs.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: Let me councell you not to expresse any violence in your passions, least you marre the possibility of reclayming her, it seemes Aymwell ha's mist the intelligence, where shame is inforc'd too much vpon the delinquent, it begets rather an audacious defence of the sin, then repentance, soft raine slides to the root, and nourishes, where great stormes make a noyse, wet but the skin a'th earth, and runne away in a channell.

sp.speaker: Sen:
sp.p: A most rare proiect.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: It will appeare the same, both made together
Which since my sisters death I haue worne.

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.p: Which of my cares reward'st thou with this folly.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Sir can you pardon?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I loue you but too well, goe to your chamber.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.p: But must wee part.

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.p: Dispute it not.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: Bu'y sweet Mistris Sensible, I hope wee shall meete againe as merry as we part.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: 'Tis very violent, but wee obey your pleasure, I haue onely apparrell and some few trifles.

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.p: Take 'em all we'e and be gone.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Beside my owne misfortune, I haue cause to pitty thine, my father is displeas'd, and not iniustly, happy genius.— Exeunt

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.p: So, things must be mannag'd wisely, I will hasten the marriage.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: By all meanes let it be suddaine.

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.p: Within two dayes— to morrow.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: I wo'not sleepe, till shee be married, but carry things smooth, let not the Knight suspect y'are troubled, your daughter will be fetc'ht about with a byas againe.

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.p: How thou deseru'st me, let vs in.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.l: Hereafter for my sake, and subtle paines
Who ere is wise, let the world call him Braines.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: CAn this be true?

sp.speaker: Sen:
sp.p: As I haue faith to heauen.

sp.speaker: Aym:
sp.l: Take this and this for thy sweete story, thou
Hast entranc'd me with thy language; laden
With my dispaires, like a distressed barke
I gaue my selfe vp lost in the imagin'd
Tempest, but at point of striking
Vpon a rocke, what a caelestiall gale
Makes my sayles swell with comfort, and enforcing
My ship into the channell, I doe feele it
Bound on the waues, discretion at the helme
Which passion made forsaken, I now blesse
The Minute I weighed Anchor; oh my destiny
Dwell longer on this threed and make it firme,
Vpon it hangs the weight of such a fortune
That if it cracke, will swifter then Ioues flaming
Arrow, digge my graue i'th earths center,
Forgiue me sacred sexe of women that
In thought or sillable I ha declaym'd
Against your goodnesse, I will redeeme it
With such religious honouring your names
That when I dye some neere thought stained Virgin
Shall make a relicke of my dust, and throw
My ashes like a charme vpon those men,
Whose faithes they hold suspected, to what pitch
Of blessednesse are my thoughts mounted.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Sir,
This is an opportunity for action
Time will runne fast vpon the minute.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Pardon
The trespasse of my ioy it makes me vilde
I am too well rewarded for thy suffering
Promise thy selfe a noble recompence.

sp.speaker: Man:
sp.p: Come ha you finisht your discourse yet.

sp.speaker: Aym:
sp.l: Y'are my friends,
I was deceiued in my Violetta
Shee loues, sh'as sent me proofe, but a mistake
Sent backe my letter, and detain'd her answere
Which was betray'd to her father, but keepe your wonder
To honour her rare wit, which if the starres
Shew themselues not malicious, will assure
All my desires in her, a diuine proiect
She is the master engine, you must worke too,
Will you not friends?

sp.speaker: Both:
sp.p: You know you may commaund vs.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: Then spread your bosomes, you shall straight procure
A caroach be ready a'th backside a'my lodging,
Doe not loose time in questioning, my fate
Depends vpon your hast.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Promise it done.

sp.speaker: Aym:
sp.p: You shall disguise your selfe I must employ you in rougher action.

sp.speaker: Clar:
sp.l: I refuse no office
To aduance your hopes.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: My certaintie's, in thee,
The frame of our whole building leanes, come on
Moue slowly time vntill our worke be done. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: I was not blind to your deserts.
Nor can be so vngratefull now, as not
To giue encouragement to your affection
My father may commaund my person, neuer
My loue to marry Treedle.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Hee's an asse I made his best verses for 'em.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I thought his fancy would not reach 'em.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: His sconce is drier then a Pumice.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: There be wayes to preuent marriage for I'me already changed.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Y'are wise, lets run away together.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: But how shall I be sure your loue is firme.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Try me and trust me after.

sp.speaker: Vio.
