sp.p: And I will, for shall it be a hard taske Ile impose on you, dare you fight?

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: If I like my enemy.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: 'Tis a poore old fellow.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: Then I'le kill him, his name?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My fathers seruant Braynes.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.l: Hee's dead.
By this time.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Stay, there is a circumstance
To be obserued, by some meanes I'le procure
He waites on me to the Strand this afternoone.
Sir Nicholas? your eare for the rest.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.l: He will suspect nothing by our priuacy,
He bad me take occasion to vrge
His good parts to you, should hee aske I'de sweare
I did but presse his commendations.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Is thy name Whible.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Yes, and't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I like thee the better for that my name's Treedle.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: I thanke your worship.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Hast done hooking a me.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Euery eye hath his obiect already.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: A witty knaue, what place dost thou occupie vnder thy Master.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: I am commonly his journey-man Sir.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: I looke to his Horses sir.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Wo't serue mee when I'me married.

sp.speaker: Whi.
sp.p: Alas, I haue no good parts to commend men.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No good parts, and thou hast but skill in Horses and Dogs, th'art fit for any Gentleman in England.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Iust at that place assault him.

sp.speaker: Tu.
sp.p: By your faire hand I will.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: My Delight, how fare you.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I'me studying some witty Poesie for thy wedding Ring, let me see—

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Trouble not your head, Whible intreat my Father hither.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No matter, I will send to the Vniuersity.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Were you euer of any Colledge?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Colledge, I haue had a head in most ath' Butteries of Cambridge, and 't has beene sconc'd to purpose. I know what belongs to Sizing and haue answered to my Que in my dayes, I'me free of the whole Vniuersity, I commencd with no worse then his Maiesties footmen.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And euer since you haue had a running wit, you were better consult our wits at home, wee haue excellent Poets i'th Towne they say.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I'th Towne? What makes so many Schollers then come from Oxford and Cambridge, like Market women with Dorsers full of lamentable Tragedies, and ridiculous Comedies which they might here vent to the Players, but they will take no money for 'em.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Oh my dearest! How happie shall I bee when I'me married. Kisse.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Looke, they are ingendering at the lip.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I like it well.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Why are our ioyes defer'd?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: But till to morrow.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: 'Tis an age me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Kind worme.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: This cannot be deceit.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I want some trifles the Exchange will furnish me, Let it be your motion to my Father.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p:
Father and Vncle you will excuse our familiar conuersation; I vow Ile bee honest till I be married, nor as
touch of my flesh within the walls, onely the suburbs of her lips or hands, or so, and when, and when is to morrow the day, the day of coupling and so forth, haue you got a licence.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: It shall be my next worke:

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Pray doe, weel'e bee marryed here, but keepe our wedding at my owne house at Croidon, wee'le ha the City Waites downe with vs, and a noise of Trumpets, we can haue Drummes i'th Country, and the Traine-Band, and then let the Spaniards come and they dare, dost heare; heere's twenty peeces you shall fribble e'm away at the Exchange presently.

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.p: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Nic:
sp.p: By this gold she shall Father, lay it out in Tooth-picks, I'le weare 'em out in my hat; come I'le with you for the lycence.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Who shall with her?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I must attend a proiect of my daughters. Exit.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Braines.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Geo:
sp.p: Waite on my daughter to the Exchange, obserue her carefully.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: point me a minute to returne with her, if I faile put my braines into'th pot, and let 'em be seru'd vp with a Calues head, to morrow dinner.

sp.speaker: Vio:
sp.p: It succeeds to my wish.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Violetta, look you lay out my gold at the Exchange in Bartholomew Fairings, farewell Violetta.

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: Come Mistris will you walke, I would faine see any mortall wit couzen me a my charge now, I will liue to be the shame of Pollititians, and when I am dead, be clapt vp into the Chronicles.

sp.speaker: Fow:
sp.p:
Ah the desire of vnlawfull flesh, what a coniuring dost thou keepe within vs to lay this little spirit of conscience, the world and the divell, are tame and sprightlesse
temptations, poore traffique to this staple commoditie of Whooring: this is the place where I must take shipping for the Summer Islands, if she keepe touch, I will call them fortunate, and once a Weeke make a Love voyage to them. Ha! are we entertayn'd with Musicke?

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Backe, backe againe, fond man forbeare,
Buy not a Minutes play too deare:
Come with Holy flame and bee
Welcome to Vertue and to mee.

sp.p: Come with Holy flame and bee, welcome to Vertue and to me? Flame? I bring none wo' me, and I should be sorry to meete any fire workes here, for those hereafter I looke on 'em a farre off, and apprehend them with lesse feare, againe?

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: Love a thousand sweets distilling,
And with Nectar bosomes filling,
Charme all eyes that none may find vs,
Be above, before, behind vs;
And while wee thy pleasures tast
Enforce Time it selfe to stay,
And by fore-locke hold him fast
Least occasion slip away.

sp.p: I marry, this is another manner of invitement, I'le to her but— Enter Winifrid .Heere comes the squire of her Mistresses body, how does my little taper of Virgin waxe, thou hast beene in some dampe thou burnst blew me thinkes.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Noble Sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: What, a cold.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: A great cold, I ha lost my voyce.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: And thou hast not lost thy Maydenhead 'tis no matter, have a little care of thy Francke Tenement, and thy tongue will come time enough to it selfe Ile warrant thee, what place has she chosen for the Encounter?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Her chamber.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Her chamber?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: 'Tis all darke.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Is't all darke, I commend her pollicy the better, then the roome, and the deed that must bee done in't will be of one complexion, so shee be light I care not, prethee convey me to her.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Follow me.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: As thy shadow woe bee to some a the deere sexe when a Chambermaid is Vsher to a Gentleman. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: It shall be a harmelesse tryall Sir.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Goe too, I know thou art vertuous, put in execution thy purpose, I'le be within the reach of thy voyce.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: It shall be my security,
What ill starre, rul'd at my Natiuity,
That I should be so miserable to loue
A man, whose glory is his vice, whose study
Is but to ruine vertue. Enter Winifrid.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Mistresse?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Heere Winifrid.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: The Gamester waytes his entrance iocund as a Bridgegroome, hee has forgot his Feauer.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Away you know your charge, be ready where are you Sir, Mr. Fowler She speakes hoarse. Enter Fowler.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Hell, if darknesse will carry it, yet hell cannot be so blacke.
There are too many flames in't, thy hand, what Monkes hole hast thou brought me to, where's thy Mistris.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: This is the way.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Is this the way? it is a very blind one, the Diuell can hardly know me if hee meet me heere that's my comfort, yet if hee did, he loues the sinne too well to interrupt so precious a meeting, prethee Child of darknesse conduct me to the handsome Fairie I must dance withall.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: It seemes your Feauer hath left you.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p:
My Feauer, I forget my selfe, I should haue counterfeited sicke all this while, but no matter and thy Mistris know it not, thou art skilfull in secrets, and I will deserue it: two or 3. fits when I am in her presence, will make her keepe her
promise, wo'me about the cure, for that she thinkes I was so, prethee doe thy office and bring me to her, I hope she is not within hearing.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Feare not.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: So about it then.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: There's a fee belongs to my place first:

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: A fee belonging to your place, as I hope for a limbe of thy Mistresse I had forgot it, there's gold I can feele it by this darkenesse: for thou seest I haue no light to sweare by 'tis weight, quicke periwincle to thy mistris now.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: This is not enough.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: There's more, take siluer and all.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: This is nothing.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Is it nothing? by this hand wo'd I could see't, tis all I haue, wo't search me?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: There is another Fee belongs to vs.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Another Fee belongs to us? what's that? I must kisse her, th'hast a down lip, and dost twang it handsomely, now to the businesse.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: This is not all I looke for:

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Shee wo'not tempt me to come aloft will she?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: If you could see me I doe blush;

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: What does my daughter meane?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: If I could see her shee does blush shee; sayes tis so: oh the insatiable desires of Chamber-maydes! they were wont to looke no higher then the Groome or Seruingman and be thankefull, or if the Master would be pleased to let 'em shew him this lobby to'ther withdrawing chamber, or the turret in summer, and take occasion to commend the scituation and so forth, 'twas after the Lady had beene seru'd, out of his owne meere motion and fauour, and 'twas taken as an endearement for euer of their seruice and secrecie, now they must be tasters to'em i'the sweete sinne, Fees o'the Court must be payed, or no suit commenc'd with iniquity, O Venus, what will this world come to?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Heare me.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: Yes, I cannot see thee.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: This chamber by my policy was made darke:

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: This chamber by your policy was made darke, so.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: My Mistris expected you without this ceremony.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Your Mistris expects me, &c. cunning Gipsey.

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: But if you condiscend not first:

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: But if I condiscend not first, will she threaten me?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: To impart to me the sweet pleasure of your body.

sp.speaker: Fow:
sp.p: To impart to you the sweet pleasure of my body,

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: Indeed you shall not imbrace my Mistris and so forth.——

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Indeed I shall not imbrace your Mistris and so forth, you will iustifie this to her face, tis not that I stand vpon a cariere, but I wo'not be compeld to lye with any Whore in Christendome, was euer such a Goate in nature, why harke yoe virgin aboue ground, for a darke roome or a sellar are all one for you, you that are a degree aboue the Kitchin, and make your Masters man run mad to heare you play ath' Virginals, whose breath though strengthned with garlicke, you wo'd sucke like a domesticke Catte at midnight, will no dyet downe with you; but what is reserued for your Mistresses pallate, you are in hope to filch a point from my breeches, which executed at both ends, you will weare about your smutchy wrist for a bracelet, I will seeke out thy Mistris, rifle her Lady-ware in spight of thee, and giue my footmen charge not to kisse thee, and it would keep thee from starving, would I could see the way out agen:

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I can betray and will.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Shee'le betray vs, she has voyce enough for such a mischiefe, dost heare, doe but consider she is thy Mistris, there's some reason she should be prefer'd.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Il'e heare none.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p:
Shee'le heare no reason, if the divell hath fed her blood with the hope of me, would he would furnish her with an Incubus in my shape to serue her, or let a Satyre leape her, oh vnmercifull Chambermaides, the graue is sooner satisfied then their wantonnesse, dost heare, wo't ha the
truth on't, 'twas a condition betweene vs, and I swore no woman should enioy me before her, there's conscience I should be honest to her, prethee be kind to a young sinner, I will deserue thee hereafter i'the height of dalliance.

sp.speaker: Pen:
sp.p: I am i'the same humor still.

sp.speaker: Fow:
sp.p: She is i'the same humour still, I must go through her to her Mistris, art thou a Christian?—— Well tho'rt a braue girle, and I doe loue thy resolution, and so soone as I haue presented my first fruits to thy Mistris onely for my oathes sake I'le returne and ply thee with embraces, as I am a Gentleman prethee shew me the way.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I wo'not trust you Sir,

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Wo'not you trust me? why come on then and there be no remedy.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Will you satisfie my desire?

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I'le doe my endeauour, I am vntrussing as fast as I can, nay and I be provock't, I am a Tyrant, have at you Beauchamp.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Winfryd.

sp.speaker: Fow:
sp.l: Ha you found your voyce, what
Meane you by this light?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: That you should see your shame

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: Cheated, ha?
Is this your loue to me, your noble loue
I did suspect before how I should find you,

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Degenerated man, what mad disease
Dwels in thy veynes that does corrupt the flowings
Of generous bloud within thee,

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: Shall I not vault Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: What behaviour of mine
Gave thee suspicion I could be
So lost to vertue, to giue vp mine honour,
Poore man how thou didst foole thy selfe
Goe home and pray thy sinne may
Be forgiven, and with teares
Wash thy polluted soule.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: I like this well
And find her noble ayme.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Be man againe;
For yet thou art a Monster, and this act
Published will make thee appeare so blacke and
Horrid, that euen beasts will be ashamed
Of thy society, my goodnesse in hope of
Your conuersion makes me chides you so,
Ha Winifryd dost thou obserue him, oh my heart
Is full of feare, I tremble to looke on him:
See of a suddaine what a palenesse has
Possest his face, doe not his eyes retyre
Into their hollow chambers, Sir how doe you?

sp.speaker: Fow:
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: What new proiect's this?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: A suddaine change.
Sure heauen is iust vnto thy late imposture,
And thou art punisht now indeed with sicknes
For mocking heauen I feare, oh dost thou see.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Death sits vpon his forehead, I ne're saw
The horrour of a dying countenance,
But in this Gentleman, Winifryd to my closset,
Fetch me the Cordial,

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: What de'e meane Gentlewomen,
I doe not feele any such dangerous sicknes.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: What a hollow voyce he has, oh my misfortune
If he should die here, fetch me some strong waters.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: No no, I can walke for 'em my selfe if need be.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: He talks wildly:
I may suspect him, if y'aue so much strength
To walke, goe home, call your Physician,
And friends, dispose of your estate, and settle
Your peace for heauen I doe beseech you Sir.
My prayers shall begge a mercy on your soule:
For I haue no encouragement to hope
Your glasse hath many sands, farewell Sir, cherish
Pare holy thoughts, that if your life soone end,
Your better part may to you Court ascend, come to my Father. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: What's the meaning a this sicke and dying, I feele no paine, I haue heard of some dyed with conceite, if it should kill me, I were a precious cockscombe, was euer poore Gentleman brought into such a foolish paradise prepared for a race, and mounting into th' saddle, I must goe home and dye, well, if I liue I'le quit your cunning, and for the more centainty, my reuenge may prosper, I wo'not say my prayers till it take effect. Enter Tutor.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: This is the place where I must exercise my valour vpon Braines, I was ne're giuen to fight, but I'me engaged for such a prize as I would challenge all the Noble sciences in my owne defence.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: I cannot spye 'em, yet, pray heauen no
Disaster crosse our proiect,

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What thing's that walkes about the doore?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.l: One practising I
Thinke, the postures of a Fencer.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Things occurre worthy consideration:

Were I best to speake before I strike him, or giue him blowes, and tell him reason afterwards. I doe not like expostulations, they proclaime our anger, and giue the enemy warning to defend himselfe, I'le strike him valiantly and in silence.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: What does he mutter?

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: What busines stayes him here, some treachery.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: Being resolu'd to strike before I speake.
'Tis worth my iudgement, whether Fist or Sword
Shall first salute him, I'le be generous,
And giue him first two or three wholesome buffets,
Which well laid on, may happily so maze him,
My weapon may be vselesse, for I feare
Should I begin with steele, her very face
Would force me make too deepe incision,
And so there may be worke for Sessions,
I like not that as valiant as I am,
Killing is common.

sp.speaker: Aym.
sp.p: Clare, they are in sight, downe, downe, oh my rauisht soule, what blisse is in this obiect?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Ha they are comming, 'tis she and the old Ruffian he has but a scuruy countenance, I ha th'advantage in the first blow, and I shou'd be very sorry, he should beate me in the conclusion.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Why does this fellow stay?

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: I must on, she has spyed me through her maske,
I see her smile already, and command
A present Battery.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Will this fellow preuent my office, he goes toward him with a quarrelling face, ha, I'le not engage my selfe, then 'tis so: withdrawes

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Helpe, helpe. She runs in & presently slips out Sencible drest like her Mistris.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Mistris stay, Feare nothing, alas good Gentlewoman, you blacke Magot death, I'de treade him into the kennell amongst his kindred.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: Hold, helpe, murder,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: We shall haue the whole streete about's presently
let's on our iourney, who 's this Mole-catcher?
And ye had not beene wo'me, I would haue cut
Him into more pieces then a Taylors cushin,
Sir Nicholas you shall know on't too. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.l: They are gone together, Poxe a this toughnes,
Has made an Asse of me, next him doe I hate the Law
Most abominably, for if I might kill and not be hang'd:
sp.p: For him 'two'd neuer trouble me, shall I loose my reputation, So I'le venture an other pounding, but I'le be reveng'd on him. Exeunt

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
My Mistris is growne very thtisty of her voyce a'the sudden, I haue ask'd her 2. or three questions, and she answers me with holding out her hand, as the poste at St. Albaines that points the way to London, either shee is
growne sullen, or the fright she was in late like a Wolfe that sees a man first, hath taken away her voyce,— I'le make her speake to me— He stayes, she puts him forward with her hand.— Said you forsooth— we will not doe, what a blessed comfort shal he enioy if she continue speechlesse, the Persians did worship a God vnder the name of Silence, and sure Christians may haue an excuse for their Idolatry, if they can find a woman whom nature hath posted into the world with a tongue, but no ability to make vse of that miserable Organ, what doe you thinke 'tis a clocke? two not stroke, ha? how now Mrs. treading a toside, this is your way to the Exchange. She slips away.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: My way you sawcie Clowne, take that,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: You are bountifull, 'tis more then I look't for.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: What ha you to say to me Sirra, cannot a Gentlewoman

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Ha ah my Braines melt, I am undone, I am vndone, you Succubus where is my Mistris? Proserpine speake.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: That's he, your office.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.p: We arrest you Sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Me you Toades?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Howe's this?

sp.speaker: Tut,
sp.p: Away with him to Prison, 'tis no slight action, at your perils Sergeants— my fayrest Mistris.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.p: Mistris— I'le honour this plot for the mirth sake.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Sirra Tadpoole whatdee' meane, I owe him not a penny by this flesh, he has a conspiracy vpon me, I charge ye in the Kings name vnbind me.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.l: We charge you i'th Kings name obey vs,

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: May you liue to be arrested ath' Pox, and dye in a Dungeon, nay Innes a Court Gentleman, at next trimming shaue your eares and noses off, and then ducke you in their owne boggards.

div.head: SCENA. I.
div.stage: Enter Sir George, Sir Nicholas, Mr. Worthy.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: SO, now we have got a Lycense, I would see who dares marry your daughter besides my selfe, is she come from the Exchange yet?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Not yet Sir. Enter a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: Your servant Braines remembers his duty in this Paper.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Letters!

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Letters, let me read em.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Your patience Sir.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I doubt all is not well, what if some misfortune should now befall your Mistris, I hope you have Armour of Patience?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I and of Proofe too at home, as much as my Hall can hold, the Story of the Prodigall can hardly be seen for't; I have Pikes and Gunnes, enough for me and my Predecessors, a whole Wardrope of Swords and Bucklers, when you come home you shall see 'em.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: A Conspiracy.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Oh Treason.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: My man Braines is arrested by your Tutor, a plot to take away my daughter, she is gone.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I did prophesie too soone.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: My Tutor read travell to me, and run away.
With my Wench— a very Peripatetike— what shall I doe then, and some had arrested and clapt her up too— we should have knowne where to find her— dee heare, I did not meane to marry with a License.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No Sir, I did meane to marry with your daughter Am I a Gull?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Have Patience.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I will have no patience, I will have Violetta, why does not Braines appeare?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: His heeles are not at liberty, he's in Prison.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: In Prison, why and he had beene hanged, he might have brought us word.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I'me rent with vexation, Sirra goe you with me to the Prison. Exit George and Messenger.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: What will you doe?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Ile geld my Tutor.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: You were best finde him first.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Nay I will finde him, and find him agen and I can light on him, let me alone, Ile take halfe a doozen wo'mee and about it instantly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I wish thee well Neece, but a better husband.
Who's yonder, 'tis Master Fowler, at an excellent opportunity. Exit.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I doe walke still, by all circumstance I am alive, not sicke in any part but my head, which has only the pangs of invention, and is in travell of some pretious revenge, for my worse then Masculine affront, what if I report abroad shee's dishonest, I cannot doe'em a worse turne then to say so: some of our Gallants take a pride to belye poore Gentlewomen a'that fashion, and thinke the discourse an honour to 'em; confidently boast the fruition of this or that Lady, whose hand they never kist with the Glove off: and why may not I make it my revenge, to blurre their fames a little for abusing me.

div.stage: Enter two Friends at severall Doores.

sp.p: Well met friend, what? thou lookest sad.
You will excuse me, and beare a part, when I tell the cause.
What's the Newes?
Our Friend Master Fowler's dead.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Fowler! Ha?
Mr. Iohn Fowler.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: That's I, that's I, ha?
The same.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Dead, am I dead?

sp.l: It cannot be, I saw him but this morning
Lusty and pleasant, how dyed hee?

sp.p: Suddenly.
Where?
At Master Worthies house.
Dead!
Too true Sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I wo'd not beleeve my selfe sicke, belike I am dead, 'tis more then I know yet.
He was a Sutor to Master Worthies daughter.
Mistris Penelope, right.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: By all circumstance they meane me, these Gentlemen know me too, how long is it since I departed? Some mistake—

sp.l: How poore a thing is life, that we cannot
Promise a Minutes certainty, i'th height
And strength of youth, falling to dust agen.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Ha, ha, Gentlemen, what d'ee thinke a'the dead man?
'Tis the last Office I can doe him, now to waite on him to the Earth.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Coxcombes d'ee not know me, I'me alive, dee not see me?

sp.l: He was a noble Fellow, and deserves
A memory, if my braine have not lost
All his Poeticke juyce, it shall goe hard
But Ile squeeze out an Elegie.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: For whom my furious Poet, ha, not know me, doe I walke invisible, or am I my owne Ghost, and you wo not see me, you shall feele me, you have a nimble pate, I may chance strike out some flash of wit— no—
Here comes another, save you Master Worthy.
Sir I heard ill newes, Master Fowlers dead.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: He is indeed Sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Indeed you lye Sir.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: I saw his eyes seal'd up by death, and him
Rapt in his last sheet.

sp.p: Where's his body?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: At my sad house Sir.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Is my body at your house?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: I did hope Gentlemen, we should ha found
My house his Bridall Chamber, not his Coffin.
But Heaven must be obey'd, my daughter lov'd him,
And much laments his losse.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Very good, then I am dead, am I not?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: You both were in the number of his friends,
I hope you'll adde your presence to the rest, a'the Funerall.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Whose Funerall, you man of Bedlam.
Cry mercy Sir, pray keepe your way.

sp.l: It is a duty which without invitement
We are both prompt to discharge.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Master Worthy, Gentlemen d'ee heare. Ex. man. Fow. Is't possible, not know me, not see me, I am so thinne, and aery, I ha slipt out a'the world it seemes, and did not know on't— if I be dead, what place am I in, where am I? This is not Hell, sure I feele no torment, and there is too little company, no 'tis not Hell— and I ha not liv'd after the rate of going to Heaven; yet beside, I met iust now a Vsurer, that onely deales upon ounces, and carries his Scales at his Girdle, with which he uses to weigh, not mens necessities, but the Plate he is to lend mony upon, can this fellow come to Heaven? Here a poore fellow is put i'th stockes for being drunke, and the Constable himselfe reeling home, charges others i'th Kings name to ayde him. There's a spruce Captain, newly crept out of a Gentleman Vsher, and shufled into a Buffe Iurkin with gold Lace, that never saw service beyond Finsbury or the Artillery Garden, marches waving a desperate Feather in his Ladies beaver, while a poore Souldier, bred up in the Schoole of Warre all his life, yet never commenc'd any degree of Commander, wants a peece of Brasse, to discharge a wheaten Bullet to his? belly no— this is not Heaven I know by the people that traffique in't, where am I then? Vmh Ile to Worthies before they bury me, and informe my selfe better what's become a me, if I finde not my selfe there in a Coffin, there's hope I may revive agen, if I be dead, I am in a world very like the other, I will get me a female spirit to converse withall and kisse, and be merry, and imagine my selfe alive againe. Exit.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come follow me, and be valiant my Masters.

sp.speaker: Whib.
sp.p:
Remember your selfe Sir, this is your Worships Footeman, and for mine owne part, though I be not cut
according to your cloth, I am a true Servant of yours, where d'ee think we shall finde 'em?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Where? where dost thou thinke?

sp.speaker: Footm.
sp.p: I thinke where his worship thinkes

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No matter, whether we find 'em or no, but when we have taken 'em, as if they be not 'tis their owne fault, for we are ready, for Violetta upon submission, I will commit marriage with her, but for the Rogue my Tutor—

sp.speaker: Whib.
sp.p: What will you doe with him?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Ile doe nothing to him, thou shalt kill him for me.

sp.speaker: Whib.
sp.p: It will shew better in your Footman.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Thou sayest right, he can run him through quickly, but 'tis no matter who, and the worst come to worst, 'tis but a hanging matter, and Ile get a pardon first or last, I would kill him my selfe, but that I should bee taxed to kill a poore worme, more then ever I did in my life, besides 'tis not with my credit to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Whib.
sp.p: And please your Worship, Ile make a faire motion, take your choyce Sir Nicholas, whether we shall kill him and you'll be hang'd for him, or you shall be hang'd for him and we'll kill him.

sp.speaker: Footm.
sp.p: Vnder correction, I think it were better to take him Prisoner.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: I like my Footmans reason, we'll take him first Prisoner, and whosoever hath a minde to be hang'd, may kill him afterwards—- oh that I had him heere now, I could cut him in pieces on my Rapiers point.

sp.speaker: Whib.
sp.p: Has not your worship beene at Fence Schoole?

sp.speaker: Nic
sp.p: At Fence Schoole? I think I have, Ile play so many for so many, I name no weapons, with any High German, English Fencer of them all—- Canst not thou Fence Whibble?

sp.speaker: Whib.
sp.p: I Sir alas—

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: 'Tis but thus and thus, and there's a man at your Mercy, I would cleaue a Button, and 'twere as broad as the brim of your hat now, oh that I had but any Friend. but to kill a litle, prethee try me Whibble.

sp.speaker: Whib.
sp.p: I am none of your friends.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Why then and thou lovest me, be my foe a litle, for a bout or so.

sp.speaker: Whib.
sp.p: I care not much to exercise your Worship, stand aside.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Stay let me see first— there's it— I cannot with my honour wound thee, I doe not stand upone the oddes of my weapon which is longer than thine, but thou seest thine is shorter than mine by a handfull, too much is too much.

sp.speaker: Footm.
sp.p: Your Tutor Sir, and Mistris Violetta.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: How! Downe with him some body— hee's gone, follow him close— Oh run away cowardly rascall, will ye not fight against three? Mistris it is my fortune you see or my destiny, to recover your lost Virginity, I am sorry for nothing, but that I ha shed no bloud in your rescue: but where there is no valour to be expected, 'tis best to put up with valour and reputation, would the Rascall my Tutor have popt in before me? I'm glad I have prevented him,— dee heare— your father's mad, and I'm litle better my selfe, but let's be wise, loose no more time, I know a Parson shall divide us into man and wife ere any body think on't, Ile make all sure now, Ile not be put into any more of these frights, Ile marry you, if any man dare run away with you afterward, let it light upon mine owne head, and that's the worse I am sure they can doe me.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Gentlemen I thanke you, you carried it To my desire most cunningly.
D'ee thinke 'thas taken?
I am covetous to see the event.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Pray sit—- Penelope
In mourning.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: All parties in the ingagement.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: You oblige a womans service.

sp.l: Gentle
Lady And if it prove fortunate, the designe
Will be your honour, and the deed it selfe
Reward us in his benefit, he was ever wilde

sp.p: Assured your ends are noble, we are happy in.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Master Fowler.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Is he come already?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Remove the hearse into this Chamber
In your noblenesse, I desire you will
Interpret fairely what I am to personate
And by the Story you will finde I haue
Some cause of passion.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: This is the roome I sickned in, and by report dyed in, umh I have heard of spirits walking with aeriall bodies, and ha beene wondered at by others, but I must only wonder at my selfe, for if they be not mad, I'me come to my owne buriall, certaine these clothes are substantiall, I owe my Taylor for 'em to this houre, if the Divell bee not my Taylor, and hath furnish'd me with another suit very like it— This is no magicall noyse, essentiall gold and silver? What doe I with it if I be dead? Here are no reckonings to be payd with it, no Taverne Bils, no midnight Revels, with the costly Tribe of amorous she sinners, now I cannot spend it, would the poore had it, by their prayers I might hope to get out of this new pittifull Purgatory, or at least know which way I came in to't— Here they are in mourning, what a Divell doe they meane to doe with me— not too many teares Lady, you will but spoyle your eyes, and draw upon 'em the misery of Spectacles, doe not you know me neyther?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Oh Master Fowler.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Ha, out wa't, nay and the woman but acknowledge me alive, there's some hope a me.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I loved thee living with a holy flame to purge the errours of thy wanton youth.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I'me dead againe.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: This made thy soule sue out so hasty a Divorce.
And flee to aery dwellings, hath
Left vs thy cold pale figure, which wee haue
Commission but to chamber vp in
Melancholly dust, where thy owne wormes
Like the false servants of some great man shall
devoure thee first.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: I am wormes meate,

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: We must all dye.

sp.speaker: Fow:
sp.p: Woo'd some of you would do't quickly, that I might ha company,

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: But wert thou now to liue againe with vs
And that by miracle thy soule should with thy
Body haue second marriage, I beleeue
Thou woo'dst study to keepe it a chast Temple, holy
Thoughts like Fumes of sacred incense houering
About this heart, then thou wo'dst learne to be
Above thy frailties, and resist the flatteries of
Smooth-fac'd lust.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: This is my Funerall sermon.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: The burden of which sinne, my feares perswade me, both hastned and accompanied thy death.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: This sorrow is vnfruitfull.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I ha done,
May this prayer profit him, woo'd his soule were
As sure to gaine heauen as his bodie's, here,

sp.p: We must hope the best, he was an inconstant young man, frequenting of some companies, had corrupted his nature, and a little debauched him.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p:
In all this sermon I haue heard little commendations of our deare brother departed, rich men doe not goe to th'pithole without Complement of Christian burial, it seemes if I had liu'd to ha made a will, and bequeathed so much legacy as would purchase some Preacher a neate Cassocke, I should ha dyed in as good estate and assurance for my soule as the best Gentleman i'th Parish, had my Monument in a conspicuous place of the Church, where I should ha beene cut in a forme of prayer, as if I had beene cal'd
away at my devotion, and so for hast to be in heauen, went thither with my booke and spectacles— do'e heare Lady and Gentlemen, is it your pleasure to see me, though not know me? and to enforme a walking busines when this so much lamented brother of yours departed out of this world, in his life I had some relation to him, what disease dyed he of pray? who is his heire yet at Common Law, for he was warme in the possession of Lands, thanke his kind father, who hauing beene in a consumption sixteene yeares, one day aboue all the rest hauing nothing els to doe, dyed, that the young man might be a Landlord, according to the custome of his ancestors:
I doubt the proiect.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: You should be his heyre or executor at least by your dry eyes, Sir I commend thee, what a miserable folly 'tis to weepe for one that's dead, and has no sence of our lamentation, Wherefore were Blackes inuented? to saue our eyes their tedious distillations, 'tis enough to be sad in our habits, they haue cause to weep that haue no mourning Cloth, 'tis a signe they get little by the dead, and that's the greatest sorrow now adayes, you lou'd him Lady, to say truth you had little cause, a wild young man, yet and hee were aliue againe, as that's in vaine to wish you know, he may perchance be more sensible, & reward you with better seruice, so you would not proclaime his weaknes,— faith speake well a'th dead hereafter and bury all his faults with him, will ye, what are these all the guests? ha? what papers? some Elegy or Epitaph? who subscribes? oh this is your Poetry.

lg.l: How he dyed some doe suppose
How he sined the Parish knowes,
Whether he's gone to heauen or hell,
Aske not me I cannot tell.

sp.p: Very well, would the Gentleman your friend were aliue to giue you thanks for 'em.
sp.l: What haue we more?

lg.l: Vnderneath, the fayre not wise,
Too selfe lou'd Narcissus lyes,
Yet his sad destruction came
From no Fountaine but a flame,
Then youth Quench your hot desires,
Purge your thoughts with chaster fyres,
Least with him it be too late,
And death triumph in your fate
Hither all you Virgins come,
Strow your teares vpon this Tombe.
Perhaps a timely weeping may
So dispose his scorched clay,
That a chast and snowy flower
May reward your gentle shower.

sp.p: Very well done vpon so dead a subiect, by the Virgin that's in't, you should owe this parcell of Poetry Lady.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: A womans muse sir,

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Oh now you can answere me, am I dead still?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Yes:

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Then you talke to a dead man.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: I doe.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Where am I dead?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Here, euery where.
Y'are dead to vertue, to all noble thoughts,
And till the proofe of your conuersion
To piety winne my faith, you are to me
Without all life, and charity to my selfe,
Bids me endeauour with this ceremony
To giue you buriall if hereafter I
Let in my memory to my thoughts, or see you.
You shall but represent his ghost or shadow
Which neuer shall haue power to fright my innocence.
Or make my cheeke looke pale, my ends are compas'd,
And here in sight of heauen.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.l: Stay,
Tha'rt a Noble girle, and dost deserue
To marry with an Emperour, remoue
This sad thing from vs, you doe know me Gentlemen
Witnesse my death to vanity, quitting all
Vnchast desires, reuiue me in thy thoughts,
And I will loue as thou hast taught me nobly
And like a husband, by this kisse the seale
That I doe shake my wanton slamber off,
And wake to vertue.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Meete it daughter.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Now you begin to liue:

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: I will grow old i'th study of my honour, this last conflict hath quite ore'come me, make me happy in the stile of your sonne.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: My blessings multiply.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: We congratulate this euent.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: See my brother. Enter Sir George, Braines.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Let not your rage be so high Sir, I ha more cause to be mad,

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Thou?

sp.speaker: Bra:
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: I haue lost my daughter.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: But I haue lost my credit, that had nothing else to liue. I was more proud of that then you could be of twenty daughters,

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Haue you found 'em?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Not, not, and yet this old Ruffian will not let me vex for it, he sayes the greatest losse is his.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p:
And I'le maintaine it, 'twas my boast that I was neuer couzned in my life, haue I betrayed so many plots, discouered letters, deciphered Characters, stript knavery to the skinne, and layd open the very soule of Conspiracie, deserv'd for my cunning to bee called Braines both Towne and Country over, and now to forfeit 'em, to see 'em drencht in a muddy stratagem, cheated by a woman, and a pedanticall lousie Woodmonger, 'tis abhominable; patience I abhorre thee, I desire him that bids me goe hang my selfe, which is the way to Surgeans Hall I'le beg to ha my skull cut, I have a suspition my braines are filcht, and my head has beene late stuft with Woodcocks
Feathers.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Be not mad.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: I will in spight of any man here, who shall hinder me if I have a minde too't.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Your happinesse removes my affliction, ha!

sp.speaker: Whib:
sp.p: Where is Sir Nicholas? we have brought the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Are you there— this was the Champion that justled me, shall I fetch a Dog-whip, or let me cut him up he will make excellent meat for the Divels Trencher, Ile carve him Sirra.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Forbeare, where is my daughter? villaine confesse.

sp.speaker: Tut.
sp.p: Alas Sir, I was waiting upon her home, Sir Nicholas met me, and tooke her from me.

sp.speaker: Geo. Wor.
sp.p: Sir Nicholas!

sp.speaker: Whib.
sp.p: Yes Sir Nicholas, hath Mistris Violetta, I am a witnesse.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Why did he iustle me, there began the treachery, aske him that?

sp.speaker: Tut:
sp.p: I pray y' sir let it be forgotten, I ha bin kickt for't.

div.stage: Enter at one Dore Mr, Aymwell, Violetta, Manly, Clare, at the other, Sir Nicholas and Sensible.

sp.speaker: Whib.
sp.p: Here she is, no there she is.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: Sir Nicholas:

sp.speaker: Wor:
sp.l: I am amaz'd:

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Stay which is my wife?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Here's my daughter.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Mistris!

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: Fine iugling. Francke whence commest?

sp.speaker: Aym:
sp.l: From the Priest, if you have any ioy for me,
We are married.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Are there not two Sir Nicholasses, pray what d'ee call this Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Aymw.
sp.p: Her name's Violetta.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Father your pardon.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p:
This is fine yfaith, well may a woman mistake her
husband, when a man that is the wiser Vessell cannot know his owne wife.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Marryed to Aymwell!

sp.speaker: Man. Cla.
sp.p: We are Witnesses.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: A good iest yfaith, hearke you, were you ever Catechiz'd? What is your name forsooth?

sp.speaker: Sens.
sp.p: Faith Sir guesse.

sp.speaker: Aymw.
sp.p: All passion will be fruitlesse but of ioy.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.l: Sensible? Came I from Croydon for a Chambermaid?
D'ee heare every body I ha married Sensible!

sp.speaker: Man. Cla.
sp.p: We are witnesses of that too.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: No no, this is my wife.

sp.speaker: Aymw.
sp.p: Touch her not with a rude hand.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Why, I know she meant to be my wife, and onely I ha married her, as folkes goe to Law, by Attourney, she is but her Deputy, for the more state I married her by proxie.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Doe not deceive your selfe Sir, though Princes depute men to marry their wives, women doe not use to be Cyphers, she is your wife in law, let me counsell you sir to prevent laughter, some body hath been couzened, I name no body, since it was your fortune to marry this wench, which cannot now be undone, seeme not to be sorry for't, they doe purpose to ieere you out of your skinne else.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Say'st thou so?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Be confident and laugh at them first, that they are so simple to think that you are guld, commend your choice, and say 'twas a trick of yours to deceive their expectation.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Come hither Madam Treedle, Gentlemen, you thinke now, I have but an ill match on't, and that as they say I am cheated, doe not beleeve it— a Lady is a Lady, a bargain is a bargain, and I'm a Knight & no Gentleman, so much for that— I grant I married her, in her Mistresses name, and though (as great men, that use to choose wives for their favourites or Servants, when they have done with 'em) I could put her off to my Footman or my Tutor here, I wo'not, I will maintain her my wife and publish her, d'ee see, publish her to any man that shall laugh at it, my owne Ladybird, and Madam Treedle.

sp.speaker: Fow.
sp.p: You are happy Sir, in being deceiv'd, he is a noble Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.l: Sir Nicholas has releast her,
Let your consent be free then.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.l: You have wonne it
Be my lov'd children, and I wish a ioy
Flow in all Bosomes. Braines we are reconcil'd.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Tutor we pardon.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: You may Sir, he was my engine, now,
What sayes my factious servant, nay, wee're friends,
The greatest Politician may bee
Deceiv'd sometimes, wit without braines yee see.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: And braines without wit too.

sp.speaker: Fowl.
sp.p: Franck thou art married, and Sir Nicholas has made a Lady, I ha liv'd loose a great while, and doe purpose to be made fast to this Gentlewoman.
sp.l: To whose act I owe my true Conversion.
When all things have their tryall, you shall find.
Nothing is constant but a vertuous mind. Exeunt.

div.p: This Play, called THE WITTY FAIRE ONE, as it was Acted on the Stage, may be Printed, this 14. of Ianuary. 1632.
